criteria.C1: Small population size and constant decline
criteria.C2: Small population size and constant decline and fragmentation, or strong fluctuations in population size
criteria.D2: Very small population size, or restricted distribution area and susceptibility to significant reduction
criteria.E: Based on the analysis, there is a significant probability that the species will disappear

excel.generate.intro: On this page you can generate an Excel template, with what you can use import many observations to Notebook. You don't have to use this template, but it will speed the import process. You can generate the template with following steps:

excel.generate.intro3: Click on "Generate" button to generate the actual template.

Make sure that the column row doesn't have multiple columns with same name. Now column "{{ambiguousColumns}}" was found multiple times.

You can remove the rows that where successfully uploaded from the file and try again. If the problem persist please contact support and if possible send the failed file along.

footer.generalPrincipals: General principles for data usage and publishing
footer.intro1: The Finnish Biodiversity Information Facility (FinBIF) is an open access data repository for researchers, government and the public. FinBIF consolidates many collections and datasets of living Finland in a single source. Our online portal, laji.fi, allows you to browse, search and download information about all forms of biological life, and to record and share your own observations. FinBIF is committed to the sharing and promotion of open access data.
footer.principalsInDepth: Detailed instructions for data usage and publishing

haseka.home.title: Save observations
haseka.intro: You can record and share your species observations at Laji.fi Notebook. The service provides adaptable forms for you to tailor your own observation record sheets. You can also choose the manner how to share your sightings with other users.
haseka.intro2:
Principles of use in brief

  1. Reported observations are published at Laji.fi portal as open data under Creative Commons 4.0. BY license.
  2. Photographs attached with the reported observations are published at Laji.fi portal. Reporter (owner) may choose the license under the photos are available for use. FinBIF is not responsible for illegitimate use of data, photographs or other information linked with the observation.
  3. Reporter may generalize the locality of the observation. This has an impact to the quality of the Laji.fi data available as open data. The authorities, however, will be able to access the accurate data recorded.
  4. Deletion of published records from the database is not possible. But the identification information, such as a name, of the reporter can be removed so that the observation becomes anonymized.
  5. The locations of species that are included in to national sensitive species list are generalized automatically.
  6. The service can be used also solely as a private notebook, but in that case, the data will not be beneficial for anyone else and is not providing any added value for e.g. biodiversity conservation.
haseka.ownSubmissions.title: Own submissions

herpetology.backgroundText: During the recent decades, considerable changes in the distribution and abundance of amphibian and reptile species have been observed worldwide. Amphibian and reptile species are good indicators of environmental health as, in general, they are sensitive to the changes in environmental conditions such as pollution, climate change and anthropogenically invaded alien species. The latest European Atlas of herpetofauna was published in the 1990's and Luomus was involved in the project as well. An intensified collection of the data will start in Finland in 2015 in order to update the current status of the species. The project is coordinated by Dr. Markus Piha, Finnish Museum of Natural History (LUOMUS).
herpetology.cover: Cover image: Böhringer Friedrich, Wikimedia commons, Creative Commons BY-SA 2.5
herpetology.intro: Finnish Museum of Natural History (LUOMUS) coordinates a research project ´Atlas of amphibians and reptiles in Finland´. The main aim of the project is to collect comprehensive knowledge on the geographical distribution of amphibians and reptiles in Finland in the decade of 2010s. Since the data will be comparable with the earlier atlas work performed in the 1980s, 1990s and early 2000s the data gathered know will provide an invaluable opportunity to study long-term changes in the distributions of individual species and herptile species diversity as a whole.
herpetology.observation: You can report your observations using the report -link on species description pages or directly using the link bellow. You can access species descriptions by clicking a species on this page's list. Species descriptions contain useful information for identifying species.
herpetology.title: Atlas of amphibians and reptiles in Finland
home.authority.text:
Welcome to the Public Authorities Portal of the Finnish Biodiversity Information Facility (FinBIF). This service is made available for environmental and natural resource managers and is not open to the unauthorised use.

The service aims to aid decision making for authorities requiring reliable biodiversity information (e.g., sustainable natural resource use and nature conservation).
home.authority.title: FinBIF - Public Authorities Portal
home.identify-help-intro: Your expertise is needed! These are the most recent images for which the subject has not been identified. You can help us to identify them!
home.inat.desc: iNaturalist Finland is part of the international iNaturalist network. Observations recorded with iNaturalist are added to FinBIF so that they are available for Finnish researchers, government and the public. Anyone can participate. All you need to do is make some observations!
home.main-page.text: The Finnish Biodiversity Information Facility (FinBIF) is an open access data repository for researchers, government and the public. FinBIF consolidates many collections and datasets of living Finland in a single source. Our online portal, laji.fi, allows you to browse, search and download information about all forms of biological life, and to record and share your own observations. FinBIF is committed to the sharing and promotion of open access data.
home.main-page.title: Finnish Biodiversity Information Facility
home.notebook-intro: Notebook Observation Management System: submit, share and manage your observations of nature. You can decide how and by who your observations and used (e.g., by citizen scientists, researchers and/or government).
home.observation-intro: Browse & Search Observations: see the taxon observations of FinBIF in tabular form and displayed on maps. All open access data can be subsequently downloaded.
home.some.title: FinBIF in Social Media
home.sponsors.title: Our partners
home.taxon-intro: Taxon search: find information about the plants, animals, fungi and other organisms of Finland. Taxon profiles contain information including distribution, traits, life-history and more.
identify.intro: Here you can browse observations without a species level identification. Click an image to see more information about the observation and a larger image. On the information page you can also suggest an identification. If you feel that based on the image it is not possible to come to a species level identification, you can check the "Unidentifiable" checkbox. When many users say an image is not identifiable, the image will no longer be shown on this page.
identify.reportIntro: Through the Notebook service, you can send unidentified observations with pictures for other FinBIF users to determine. Please note that the speed and functionality of the service depends on the activity of volunteer experts!
identify.selectIntro: You can filter the images by informal group, but the page will only be able to show those observations that can be assosiated with a group. For example the given name "fungi" can be linked but the name "some fungi perhaps?" can not be linked.
identify.toQualityPage: Browse all identifications and quality labels
invasive.description:
Early Warning System

Observations of invasive alien species (EU listed) are automatically reported (for observations submitted across all FinBIF's systems) to the Early Warning System and the alert is forwarded to the relevant authority for appropriate management action. The relevant authority is responsible for transferring these data to the EASIN service in accordance with EU regulations.

Control measure report requests can be made with the Alien Species Control form in FinBIF's Public Authority Portal. Information on the control measures implemented subsequent to an alert can be requested to assess the efficacy of the reporting and alert system.

FinBIF's services also include VISAKE, an early warning system used by the signatories to the EU Alien Species Regulation on harmful alien species (on EU list: EU 2016/1141).

iucn.home.evaluation: Read more about the implementation of the evaluation in Finland
iucn.home.intro: The Red List 2019 is the third Finnish assessment of threatened species that complies with the IUCN guidelines. The assessment involved 180 species experts and a steering group appointed by the Ministry of the Environment guided the work.
iucn.home.iucnCategories: The IUCN red-list categories used in the assessment
iucn.home.resultsIntro:
At least 48,000 species live in Finland and adequate data for assessing their vulnerability was available for 22,418 or 47% of the species. Of the species assessed, 2,667 species or 11.9% were classified as threatened. The proportion of threatened species has increased compared to the previous assessment in 2010 when 10.5% of the assessed species were classified as threatened. The development trend indicates that the target of halting the increase in the vulnerability of Finnish species has not been met.

The majority of threatened species live primarily in forests (31.2%) and in rural biotopes and other cultural habitats (24.4%). Overall, most species live in forests and rural biotopes, which partially explains the large number of threatened species in these biotopes. However, the proportionally largest number of threatened species is found in alpine habitats where only 3.6% of all assessed species are found but no fewer than 37.9% are threatened.

Changes in the forest environment are the most significant cause of threat to species, as is the case with 733 threatened species. These changes include forest management activities, the reduction of old-growth forests and large trees as well as decreasing amounts of dead and decaying wood. The second most common threat to species is the overgrowing of open habitats, which is the primary cause of threat to 639 species. Climate change poses a threat to, in particular, species in fell areas.
iucn.home.title: The Web Service of the Red List of Finnish Species
iucn.page.intro: The Web Service of the Red List of Finnish Species introduces the results of The 2019 Red List of Finnish Species. Of the 22,418 species evaluated, 2,667 i.e. 11.9 % were classified as threatened.
iucn.page.title: The Web Service of the Red List of Finnish Species

labelDesigner.Label intro:
Use this tool to design labels for your Notebook observations.

You can start from scratch and design a completely new label. You can also reuse existing labels as templates.

The Label Fields menu lists all the fields that can be included in a label. You can adjust the label and the individual fields using the Settings menu. With the File menu, you can save label design templates, download saved templates, view recent labels, and export your labels to PDF.

np.title: Names places
Filter observations based on their reliability level and dataset origin. You can use the same reliability filters as above. but also choose to include or exclude datasets based on their origin: data contributed by professionals, specialists or citizen scientists. Professionals are employed as experts in their taxa of interest. Specialists are non-professionals recognized for their expertise. And citizen scientists are any member of the community who has contributed data. Use the checkboxes beside the dataset origin type indicator to select or deselect data of all reliability levels for the given dataset origin. Or, use the checkboxes at the level below to pick and choose observations of different reliability for the different dataset origins/contributor types.

observation.horizontalBar.title: Observations per taxon
observation.info.adminStatus: Filter observations to incude those species/taxa that have one of the selected administrative properties.
observation.info.annotated: Filter observations by whether or not they have been annotated.
observation.info.area: Filter based on the repored place name (foreign municipality, locality etc).The seach is case-insensitive. For a partial (wildcard) search, add asterisk to the name, e.g. Monte C*.
observation.info.asEditor: Filter to the observations you have recored (one of the user ids linked with your account is marked as an owner of the record). You will see the non-concealed versions of your own observations (publicly open data may have been concealed for conservation or other reasons). Note: Some extremely sensitive species are not stored with exact location information to FinBIF observation search database at all, so you won't be able to see these observations even when browsing your own observations.
observation.info.asNotEditororObserver: Filter to observations, where you are not set as observer or editor (i.e. observations by other people). However, the results will also contain your observations that have been coarsened or where observer names are not public.
observation.info.asObserver: Filter to observations where you are marked as an observer (one of the user ids linked with your account is marked as an observer in the record). You will see the non-concealed versions of your own observations (publicly open data may have been concealed for conservation or other reasons). Note: Some extremely sensitive species are not stored with exact location information to FinBIF observation search database at all, so you won't be able to see these observations even when browsing your own observations.
observation.info.biogeographicalProvince: Filter with one or several biogeographical provinces. More information about provinces.
observation.info.breedingSite: Filter observations to only include breeding sites or those that have been reported not to be at a breeding site. A breeding site is a nest, spawning place etc. For now, this information is not videly reported besides bird ringing data.
observation.info.changedNames: Some taxon identifications have been corrected via quality control. For example, an observation could have been reported as "Pieris napi", but then re-identified by expert quality controllers as "Aglais urticae". If you search for observations of "Pieris" re-identified observations are not included (in this case they would appear in a search for "Aglais"). You can search for records without corrected identifications by deselecting this checkbox.
observation.info.collection: Filter to include only national museum collection specimen (Kotka collection management and Kastikka plant database)
observation.info.collectionQuality: Each dataset available in FinBIF has a quality rating. Using this filter you can narrow observations to datasets based on their quality. Read more about quality rating requirements.
observation.info.commonness:
Commonness & rarity refers specifically to Finland. Common Finnish taxa are abundant and widespread while being considered rare indicates there are few individuals found in limited regions.

Note that commonness and rarity has not been determined for all species. For insects specifically, commonness and rarity is based on so-called frequency points: common = 1-29, rare = 30-59, very rare = 60-100.
observation.info.coordinateAccuracyMax: Accuracy of the coordinates of the observation is a figure, which roughly tells how accurately the coordinates have been reported. The figure is in meters and the scale is 1m, 10m, 100m, ..., 10km, 100km. With this filter you can limit out the observations that are not accurate enough for your use.
observation.info.coordinateIntersection: With this filter you can decide how much of the area of the observation has to be inside the area you defined as a search criteria. The value 0% means, the area of the observation must at least touch the searh area. The value 100% means the observation area must be entirely inside the search area.
observation.info.count: Filter observations based on the individual count. If the observation doesn't have a reported individual count it is assumed to be 1 (also for groups where the concept of an individual is not well defined, for example mushrooms). You can provide an upper and lower limit. A "zero observation" or a "negative observation" means the taxa has not been found from the examined area. By default, negative observations are include out in searches.
observation.info.country: Filter by country. Observations from Finland have been validated to be inside Finland (if coordinates are provided), but for other countries the reported country is trusted.
observation.info.dataset: Filter observations by data source (e.g., collections, projects, datasets).
observation.info.documentId: Search by id of the specimen, document. You can provide multiple identifiers by separating them with a comma.
observation.info.effectiveTag: Filter observations based on valid tags. If an observation has been tagged (e.g., [verify location]), but later untagged, the filter will no longer apply because the original tag has been invalidated.
observation.info.finnish: FinBIF maintains a list of species considered to be 'Finnish'. The definition of which species are Finnish varies for different taxon groups. With this filter you can narrow your search to species that are Finnish (Yes) or those that are not Finnish (No).
observation.info.firstLoaded: You can filter observations based on when they have been first loaded to FinBIF. This is not always the same thing than the actual entry date, but from many sources that information is not available.
observation.info.hasDocumentMedia: Please note that Images -tab shows only observation images. Open information of the entire entry by clicking it on the Map or on the List -tab to see these images.
observation.info.hasGatheringMedia: Please note that Images -tab shows only observation images. Open information of the entire entry by clicking it on the Map or on the List -tab to see these images.
observation.info.identify: Filter observations based on whether they require identification or further taxonomic determination.
observation.info.informalTaxonGroup: You can filter observations by informal taxonomic groups. Informal groups include true taxonomic groups (e.g., Aves, or birds) as well as groups that are not recognised within a formal taxonomy. You can also use the Species/Taxa name filter to specify a taxonomic filter not included within informal groups.
observation.info.invasive: An invasive species is a species that is not native to a specific area and has been introduced by human activity. You can filter the observations to include only invasive species (Yes) or only non-invasive species (No).
observation.info.keepSsp: Include all child taxa of the taxa chosen with the Species/Taxa filter.
observation.info.keyword: Filter using a keyword, project name etc. used in one or several observations. You can provide multiple search terms by separating them with a comma.
observation.info.loaded: You can filter observations based on when they have been loaded last time into FinBIF, after being edited in the source system. Depending on the source, there might be a delay between editing and loading into FinBIF.
observation.info.maxOccurrenceFinland: Filter observations to taxa that have the selected, or less, number of observations in Finland. This can be used to search for rare species, but note that the number of observations depends on factors other than abundance.
observation.info.municipality: Filter observations based on one or more Finnish municipalities. The municipality or municipalities of an observation is either the reported municipality (no coordinates or the coordinates match with the reported municipality) or municipalities resolved using the coordinates (no reported municipality).
observation.info.nativeOccurrence: Filter observations based on the reported native status. A native observation is a plant or other organism that occurs in the location in wild. Non-native observation is for example a garden plant or domestic animal. For now nativity of observations is not widely reported. (Information is missing from most of the observations).
observation.info.needsCheck: Filter observations by tagged as requiring review. Any user can tag observations for review. New observations are automatically tagged for review by default. Expert reviewers can untag observations that no longer require view by removing the checkmark.
observation.info.qualityIssues: FinBIF applies various error checks to observations conserning location, time etc information. For example for Finnish observations we check that the reported municipality and the coordinates do not conflict. Observations that do not pass these validations are considered to have "issues" and are not shown by default by the search. If you searh your own observations, however, observations with issues are shown. You can adjust here if to include these observations or not. (Observations with issues are colored with red color on the List -tab. You can get additional information about the issue by clicking the row.)
observation.info.redListStatus: Filter observations to those species that have one of the selected Red List endangerment status in Finland.
observation.info.reliability: Filter observations based on assessment of their reliability. You may select one or more levels of reliability to include. Multiple factors determine observation reliability, including the data source and the input of experts or the citizen scientist community. Please note that FinBIF cannot guarantee that observations marked as verified are completely accurate in all respects. Users must consider reliability on a case by case basis and in the context of how they plan to use the data.
observation.info.season: Filter observations based on a repeated observation "season", for example Jan 15 to March 31. This will include all observations that have been made in any year within that range of dates. You can also use the Observation Date filter to select a season for a limited number of years.
observation.info.secured: FinBIF may coarse our open data for several reasons. You may read more about the reasons here. Using this filter you can include observations that have been secured or have not been secured.
observation.info.secureLevel: FinBIF may coarse our open data for several reasons. You may read more about the reasons here. Here you can filter by certain secure level or to those that have not been secured.
observation.info.sourceOfCoordinates: Filter to include only those observations that had coorindates in the original source. In FinBIF, those observations that do not have reported coordinates but the municipality is reported, we use coordinates of the municipality for the observation. If you want to ignore the observations for which no coordinates were originally reported, check this filter.
observation.info.stats: The numbers of hits at the Statistics-section may vary in comparison with the numbers of Observations shown in your search. This is mainly due to the difficulty to reliably link all observation with scientific classification.
observation.info.system: Filter observations by data system (e.g., database, information service).
observation.info.target:
You can filter observations by taxonomy in two ways:

1) Entering a name (or part of name) and selecting a suggested taxon from the menu. Suggestions are matched to your input if they are found in the taxonomic database. Matches include scientific names (including synonyms) and vernacular names (in Finnish, English, etc.). Selecting a taxon will return records of the specified taxon's child taxa (e.g., selecting a genus will return records of the species belonging to the genus)

2) Entering a name and pressing return without selecting a suggestion in the menu will return records that either match the input exactly for a taxon in the database (all name types), or are a full or a partial match for the taxon name as it was originally supplied to FinBIF. You can perform wildcard searches with an asterisk (e.g., "Lu*").

You can search for multiple taxa at once and you can also search by taxon ID (e.g., "MX.26280").
observation.info.team: Filter observations with one or more observer names. When you are typing an observer name, the search suggests different kinds of matching names that have been used to enter observations. Choose the names by clicking them. You can use the asterisk (*) to replace any letter(s) in the name. The search is case insensitive (does not matter whether you use capital letters or not). Note that the observations could have been entered using several types of spelling, e.g. Matti Meikäläinen; Meikäläinen, Matti; Meikäläinen, M.
observation.info.time: Filter observations with observation date. You can filter with start date, end date, or both. To limit observations to a single day, set both start and end date to the same value.
observation.info.typeOfOccurrenceId: Filter observations to include only the taxa that have one or more of the statuses that you have selected. You can also filter to include only observations that DO NOT have a certain status. The later you can do by clicking the status twice.
observation.info.typeSpecimen: Include only type specimen. A type specimen is an object in collections, which is used to describe the definition of a species or subspecies. Type specimen are especially valuable, because they stabilize concepts of scientific names.
observation.intro: FinBIF is a compilation of nature observations, museum collections and other scientific datasets from many sources. These data have been collected by academics, public authorities and citizen scientists.
observation.intro.adminStatus: Observations that match all selected features are displayed.
observation.intro.images: Filter to those observations that have
observation.intro.typeOfOccurrenceId: Filter observations according to status of species in Finland
observation.results.title: Observation search
profile.friends.needProfile: You need to make first your own profile to be able to add friends.
profile.friendsInfo: You may ask another user to become your Friend by copying your profile address (URL) and sending it to your friend. After your friend has clicked the “Add as a Friend” button, and you have confirmed his request at your own profile, you become Friends and you may e.g. make common observation records at the Notebook-observation service.
profile.defaultMediaMetadata.title: Default copyright values for photos and audio files you save to Notebook
profile.info.capturerVerbatim: Author: "Forename Surname" format recommended. Separate multiple authors with a comma.
profile.info.intellectualOwner: Author name for use in citation (e.g., 'Maija Meikäläinen, valokuvaajamaija.fi').
profile.info.intellectualRights: License. Select "All Rights Reserved" if you do not want apply a license. The images will be displayed in according to the FinBIF & Vihko Terms of Use.
profile.info.intro: Select default information to include with the photos and other media you submit to your Notebook. You can change this information for specific photos and other media from within your Notebook. Changes made here will not be applied to photos and other media that have already been uploaded.
profile.info.personalCollectionIdentifie: If you are submitting data for your personal collection in your Notebook, enter the ID (as an abbreviation or full name) here. Make sure you have contacted helpdesk@laji.fi to reserve the ID beforehand. You can make a preliminary indication of your preferred ID initially and this ID will then only appear in your private collection until the ID has been formally accepted.

quality.creator: Annotator
quality.mostActive.title: Most active annotators
result.gathering.conversions.ykj10km: YKJ 10km, whole observation area in the grid
result.gathering.conversions.ykj10kmCent: YKJ 10km, the center of the observation area

result.load.error.notLoggedIn: Log in to use this service.
result.load.error.tooManySimple: Too many results. Max size for this download is {{max}}, you’ll need to narrow the search.
result.load.intro: Your search consists of {{count}} observations of {{species}} species. {{public}} of observations are entirely public. Data from {{private}} observations has been aggregated due to restrictions on use.
result.load.introPrivate:
Your search contains {{private}} coarsened observations. Additionally it may contain hidden observations.

You can make a request to receive coarsened and hidden data. Your request will be handled individually and you'll receive additional instructions by e-mail. Justification for data use and approval of terms of use will be asked at a later stage.
result.load.introPublic: The citable download creates a file that contains all information about observations stored in FinBIF. The file is permanently stored in FinBIF services an it can be cited in publications. For citations the file will get a permanent identifier. You'll receive a link to data download page by e-mail when the download is ready. Time for download depends on the size of the data.
result.load.introSimple:
Download data from selected columns as a spreadsheet file (TSV, Excel or OpenOffice). This download doesn't contain all of the information about the observation, only the columns selected to the table of results. It's not possible to cite to this download in publications.
Follow the steps below to download a referential and comprehensive data file.
result.load.introSpecies: The observation statistics have a list of species in order of the number of observations
result.load.personalData: This feature cannot be used when searching your own observations. Remove own observations filters to continue.
result.load.thanksPublic: Thank you, you'll receive link to the data by e-mail
result.load.thanksRequest: Thank you, you'll receive additional instructions by e-mail
result.notOwnDocuments: No own submissions found with given search parameters.
result.unit.reportedTaxonConfidence: The stated certainty of the observation
saveObservations.chooseSystem: Select a tool that works for you
saveObservations.citizenScience.desc: By participating in citizen science projects, you help to gather information and learn new things about nature in Finland. Here you can take part into projects organized by different research groups and institutions. All observations are saved to Laji.fi into your own Notebook account. Explore the projects and select one to participate!
saveObservations.desc: By submitting your observations to FinBIF you can contribute to important biodiversity research. Your observations will be published on Laji.fi if you choose to make them available. You can submit single observations, maintain your own observation notebook, or take part in citizen science projects.
saveObservations.easy.3: You cannot edit the observation afterwards
saveObservations.mobile.1: Take a photo with a mobile app
saveObservations.researchProjects: Research projects and tools for public authorities
saveObservations.researchProjects.desc: Participating to research projects needs more experience than the citizen science projects. Some of the projects are only accessible for a smaller group of users.
selfUrl.introEnd: Here you can manage the user names from other systems, etc.
selfUrl.introStart: Viewing and editing user account information requires you to log in again for security reasons. After clicking the My Account button below, please log in again.
species.form.onlyPrimaryHabitat: Filter only by the primary habitat
species.title.long: The Finnish Biodiversity Information Facility maintains the national checklist of Finnish species. With the help of versatile search tool, you can familiarize with species information including e.g. descriptions, distribution maps, occurrence data, images and taxonomic relationships.
species.title.short: Browse and discover species information, descriptions and pictures.
species.tree.info.showMainLevels: Hides taxa from classification, whose taxonomic level does not belong to the main levels. Main levels are biota, domain, kingdom, phylum, class, order, family, genus and species.
species.tree.showMainLevels: Show only the main taxonomic levels

taxonomy.endangerment.iucnLink: More information on the Red List website
taxonomy.invasive.invasiveLink: See on Invasive Alien Species Portal

taxonomy.map.disclaimer: The map represents observations of this taxon, but it may not be used as a distribution map.
taxonomy.map.info: Havainnot, joiden koordinaatit ovat Suomessa, joiden laatuluokitus on neutraali tai varmistettu, ja joita ei ole merkitty tarkistusta vaativiksi.

taxonomy.ymparisto: The habitats have been mainly defined in the Finnish Species Threat Assessment 2019 and follow the national habitat classification. Read more:The Web Service of the Red List of Finnish Species – Habitat classification

theme.birdPointCount.intro: Point counts of breeding terrestrial birds
theme.census.title: Monitoring schemes
theme.checklist.intro: The annual versions of the national checklist of Finnish species.
theme.emk.intro: Information about the Finnish biogeographical provinces.
theme.grc.intro: Luomus GRC stores and loans genomic samples for academic research purposes
theme.grc.title: Luomus Genomic Resources Collection
theme.herpetology.intro: Finnish Museum of Natural History (LUOMUS) coordinates a research project ´Atlas of amphibians and reptiles in Finland´. Examine the species and the results. You can also report your own observations.
theme.hyonteisopas.intro: Identify insects to an order level
theme.identify.intro: Help identify observations! Browse images in FinBIF for which the subject has not been identified.
theme.intro: Here you can find information about important topics and services.
theme.kerttu.allCandidatesAnnotated: You have completed all the candidates for this letter. Let's move to next one!
theme.kerttu.allLettersAnnotated: You have completed all the letters of the species you have chosen in the Declare your expertise level section! Thank you very much for your valuable input for improving automated bird sound identification!
theme.kerttu.allRecordingsAnnotated: You have identified all the recordings! Thank you very much for your valuable input and improving automated bird sound identification!
theme.kerttu.areLettersSame: Is the species vocalizing in the candidate the same as the species in the letter?
theme.kerttu.confirmSkipLetter: Are you sure you want to skip the letter? All your identifications of this letter will be lost.
theme.kerttu.containsHumanSpeech: Recording contains human speech or other vocalizations
theme.kerttu.containsUnknownBirds: Recording contains bird vocalizations I cannot identify
theme.kerttu.doesNotContainBirds: No bird sounds audible in the recording
theme.kerttu.expertise.birdwatchingActiv: How actively do you engage in birdwatching?
theme.kerttu.expertise.finnishBirdSongRe: How easily are you able to identify the vocalizations of bird species occurring in Finland?
theme.kerttu.expertise.goToNext: When you have finished, using the menu on the left, navigate to section
theme.kerttu.expertise.intro: Declare your expertise level by answering the following two questions and then selecting all the species you are able to identify based on at least one of their vocalization types (i.e., song or call).
theme.kerttu.expertise.selectSpecies: Select the species vocalizations you are able to identify from the list below
theme.kerttu.info.allowNameVisible: If you allow your name to be shown to other users in the list below, select this box. By default, your name appears as “Hidden”. Your name will be shown to others only in the below list with the number of identifications you have made. Your name doesn't appear immediately in the list after selecting the box, as it takes a while to be updated.
theme.kerttu.info.areLettersSame: If you are reasonably certain about the identification, answer either Yes or No. If you are unable to hear any vocalization in the candidate box, answer No. If you are uncertain, answer I don't know.
theme.kerttu.info.changeView: With this tool, by drawing a rectangular with mouse cursor, you can zoom in to the part of spectrogram that you want to view and hear in more detail. You can also listen to the darkened areas before and after the focal part of the recording, which will help to identify sound that are partly outside the focal area. If the recording contains low-frequency background noise or other sounds which obstruct identification you can use the crop recording tool to exclude them from playback.
theme.kerttu.info.containsHumanSpeech: Select this if the recording includes human speech or other vocalization.
theme.kerttu.info.containsNoiseCausedByH: Select this if there are clearly sounds of human activity such as motor vehicles or airplanes and especially if these sounds hamper the identification.
theme.kerttu.info.containsUnknownBirds: Select this if there are bird vocalizations you cannot identify. If you included these sounds as possibly occurring in the list below, leave this unselected.
theme.kerttu.info.correlation: Correlation is a model estimate of the similarity of candidate to letter spectrograms. It does not represent the probability that the letter is the same species as the candidate. However, the correlation will be used to calculate this probability.
theme.kerttu.info.doesNotContainBirds: In case you cannot hear any bird vocalization in the recording, select this box.
theme.kerttu.info.generalCounts:
This section shows how many identifications have been made in total by all users. In letters, each candidate is counted as one identification, but in recordings, one identification corresponds to all the identifications made from one 10s recording. The number of identifications you have made is shown below, together with their share of the total identifications.
Notice that the most recent identifications may not appear immediately on this page as it may take some time for these to be updated.
theme.kerttu.info.goBackToPreviousCandid: If you have answered a question incorrectly you may return and correct your answer.
theme.kerttu.info.isLowQuality: Select this if there are rain, wind or other sources of noise which considerably hampers the listening and identification.
theme.kerttu.info.letterCandidateLonger: Clicking View will show the entire one minute spectrogram of the candidate's recording. This action will not affect the letter view, which can be adjusted by shifting the time buffer.
theme.kerttu.info.listOtherSpecies: In case there are other animal species occurring in the recordind in addition to those provided in the above list, you can add them here. You can insert also identification of higher taxonomic levels than species (e.g. amphibians - class Amphibia)
theme.kerttu.info.listSpecies: Insert the species you identified to the list below. In case you are reasonably uncertain of the identifications, choose "Occurs possibly" from the list below, other wise keep the selection at "Occurs certainly" if you are reasonably sure bout the identification. If the species you have identified does not occur in the given list, you can add the species to the list below "Insert another animal species occurring in the recording but not on the above list".
theme.kerttu.info.nextRecording: Once you are ready with the identification and recording classifications, you are free to move to the next recording. Record at least the species you can identify, but also if it contains bird vocalizations you cannot identify or no bird vocalization at all.
theme.kerttu.info.previousRecording: If you accidentally click this button or realise after you click it that you forgot to include an identification, you can go back and amend your identifications by clicking this.
theme.kerttu.info.recordingAnnotation: Listen to the 10 second sound recording and enter all the bird and other animal species you can identify. Indicate, by selecting the appropriate check boxes, if the recording is of such low quality that it impairs identification, if you can hear human voices in the recording, if there are no birds vocalizing, or there is a bird you cannot identify. When you have completed these tasks, click "Save and move to next recording".
theme.kerttu.info.saveRecording: If you need to stop before you are done click the save button. By doing so, the identifications you have made for the current recording are saved and the next time you return to Kerttu.
theme.kerttu.info.setDefaultSettings: Return the time buffer to 1s and the focus frequency option to "On".
theme.kerttu.info.skipLetter: You can choose to skip a letter if the sound is unfamiliar or identification is too difficult. Please note that if you skip a letter any identifications you have made of that letter will be discarded.
theme.kerttu.info.targetFrequency: By focusing the frequency you can exclude uninformative frequencies below and above the candidate in the spectrogram and audio. If the recording contains low frequency background noise you should keep frequency focusing on.
theme.kerttu.info.taxon: The species vocalising the letter. The letter ID is shown in parentheses.
theme.kerttu.info.timeBuffer: By modifying the time buffer you can adjust time window around the candidate. Increase the buffer if you wish to see and hear a longer span of the recording. Modifying the buffer simultaneously adjusts the letter's time window.
theme.kerttu.intro: Identify bird vocalizations and help us to teach computer to identify birds sounds automatically
theme.kerttu.isLowQuality: Recording is of poor quality (disturbing noise, rain etc.)
theme.kerttu.letterCandidateLonger: Longer sample of the candidate's recording
theme.kerttu.listOtherSpecies: Insert another animal species occurring in the recording but not on the above list:
theme.kerttu.listSpecies: Insert bird species occurring in the recording:
theme.kerttu.nextRecording: Save and move to next recording
theme.kerttu.nextRecording.validation: Insert at least one bird species or select either "Recording is of low quality (disturbing noise, rain etc.)", "No bird sounds audible in the recording" or "Recording includes bird vocalizations I cannot identify".
theme.kerttu.notEnoughLetterAnnotations: Before moving to this section, do identifications to at least 20 letters in the section Identify letters.
theme.kerttu.notSupported: Web Audio API is not supported in this browser!
theme.kerttu.recordingAnnotation.leaveCo: Are you sure you want to leave and discard the unsaved changes?
theme.kerttu.recordingAnnotation.title: Identify species occurring in the recording
theme.kerttu.result.allowNameVisible: Allow others to see my name
theme.kerttu.result.equality: The similarity between your and other users' identifications
theme.kerttu.result.equality.description: Once suffice amount of identifications are made, here a section will be added here with species specific similarities between identifications of yours and other users.
theme.kerttu.result.name: Name
missing from the list of identifiable species you have chosen in the Record your expertise section. Do you want to add the species to the list?
theme.kerttu.taxonExpertiseMissing: Please complete the section Declare your level of expertise before continuing.
theme.linetransect.intro: Line-transect count survey is a method to get a representative image of birds nesting in the area. Explore out the results, reserve a line, and report results.
theme.map.intro: This service can be used to find out coordinates in different Finnish and global coordinate systems, calculate distances and areas, and look at different maps (topographic laser map, forest vegetation zones, etc.). You can also save the patterns you draw and bring your own patterns to the service in a variety of file formats.
theme.nafi.intro: National butterfly survey of Finland (NAFI). Explore results and report observations.
theme.names.title: Taxonomy
theme.observation.title: Observations
theme.place.title: Geographic Information
theme.protax.genericError: There was an error uploading the file.
theme.protax.invalidSequence: Invalid file type. Only FASTA files are currently supported.
theme.protax.noSequence: Begin by entering the sequence in the text field or select a file to upload.
theme.protax.sequenceDescription: Enter the DNA sequence (FASTA formatted) in the text field below or select the file using the selector.
theme.research.intro: Tools and examples of FinBIF data research use.
theme.research.title: Research Tools
theme.satellite.intro: Satellite transmitters and other positioning devices provide detailed information on migratory birds, wintering areas, catchment areas and the extent of the territories. Follow the birds on the map!
theme.title: Theme pages
theme.wbc.intro: Winter bird census studies prevalence and abundance of birds in different habitats in different parts of our country and on a long time scale. Examine the results and report census results.
theme.ykj.intro: Learn about the Uniform Coordinate System (YKJ) and its use in the life sciences.

viewer.notFound: The submission has not yet been stored in the FinBIF's data warehouse. Please wait a while.
viewer.notPublished: Submission has not been published yet.

viewer.secured.none: There is no secured data in this submission.
viewer.secured.own1: This is the private view of the submission. The public view may look different

vihko.home.form.matrix.desc: Observations from a single location, over several days.
vihko.home.form.mobile.desc: Record single observations quickly with a mobile device.
vihko.home.form.save.desc: Record observations with a spreadsheet file (Excel or such).
vihko.home.form.trip.desc: Versatile form for recording multple observations from a single field trip.

vihko.home.title: Save observations
vir.page.title: Public Authority Portal | FinBIF
wbc.instructions.title: Winter bird counting with your Notebook
wbc.stats.abundance.info: Frequency: the number of individuals recorded for every 10kms surveyed
wbc.stats.abundanceComparison.info: Relative frequency: recorded frequency (individuals/10km) as percentage of average frequency for last 10 years.
wbc.stats.average.info: Keskiarvo lasketaan valittua talvea edeltävistä 10 talvesta.
wbc.stats.difference.info: Ero lasketaan valitun talven ja sitä edeltävien 10 talven keskiarvon väliltä.
wbc.stats.frequency.info: Yleisyys kertoo kuinka monella prosentilla reiteistä laji on havaittu.
wbc.stats.route.table.info: Punainen tausta: lintuja ainakin 50 % vähemmän kuin keskimäärin (lasketaan vain lajeille, joita keskimäärin ainakin 5 yksilöä); vihreä tausta: lintuja ainakin 100 % enemmän kuin keskimäärin; vihreä numero: ennätys; punainen numero: vähyysennätys.

whatsNew.message: laji.fi is a test portal for Finnish Biodiversity Information Facility. Information and properties will be improved continuously. Feedback is welcome - you can send it by feedback form or by e-mail to address info@laji.fi. Thank you!
